Subgroup

Let $G$ be a monoid. A subset $H \subset G$ is called a submonoid if $H$ satisfies the following conditions: (i) $e \in H$, (ii) $a, b \in H \Longrightarrow a b \in H$. If $G$ is a group, $H$ is called a subgroup of $G$ if in addition, (iii) $a \in H \Longrightarrow a^{-1} \in H$. In particular, a subgroup of a group $G$ is a submonoid that is closed under the process of taking inverses. In defining a subgroup $H \subset G$, condition (i) can be weakened by simply requiring $H \neq \emptyset$, since this implies $e \in H$ using (ii) and (iii). Of course, similar reasoning is not possible for monoids. Every group $G$ admits $\{e\}$ and $G$ as trivial subgroups. Given $m \in \mathbb{Z}$, the set $m \mathbb{Z}$ consisting of all integral multiples of $m$ is a subgroup of the additive group $\mathbb{Z}$. We will see in 1.3/4 that all subgroups of $\mathbb{Z}$ are of this type. More generally, every element $a$ of a group $G$ gives rise to a so-called cyclic subgroup of $G$. It consists of all powers $a^{n}, n \in \mathbb{Z}$, where we put $a^{n}=\left(a^{-1}\right)^{-n}$ for $n<0; see also Section 1.3.
Order of an element
The order of an element $a$ in a group $G$ is defined as the order of the cyclic group generated by $a$ in $G$. It is the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $a^{m}=1$.
Subring

A subset S of a ring R is called a subring if S is a subgroup with respect to the addition on R and a submonoid with respect to the multiplication on R. S inherits the laws of composition from R and is itself a ring.
Intersection of Ideals
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the intersection $\mathfrak{a} \cap \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{x ; x \in \mathfrak{a} \text { and } x \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Prime Ideal
A proper ideal $\mathfrak{p} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a prime ideal if for elements $a, b \in R$, $ab \in \mathfrak{p}$ implies $a \in \mathfrak{p}$ or $b \in \mathfrak{p}$.
Irreducible Polynomial
A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ is irreducible if it cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$.
Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields
The Galois group of a polynomial equation is the group of automorphisms of the splitting field of the polynomial that fix the base field. These automorphisms permute the roots of the polynomial.
Integral Element over a Ring

An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.
Trivial Algebraic field extension
An algebraic field extension $L / K$ is trivial if every element of $L$ is algebraic over $K$.
Centralizer
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The centralizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $Z_{S}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in S\} .$
Element of a Set
An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.
Set
A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A subgroup is defined as a subset of a group that satisfies certain conditions. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a subgroup is.
The order of an element in a group is defined in terms of the cyclic group generated by that element. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand the order of an element.
A subring is defined as a subset of a ring that satisfies certain conditions. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a subring is.
The intersection of ideals is defined in terms of ideals in a ring. Therefore, the concept of an ideal must be defined to understand the intersection of ideals.
A prime ideal is defined as a proper ideal in a ring that satisfies certain conditions. Therefore, the concept of an ideal must be defined to understand what a prime ideal is.

An irreducible polynomial is defined as a polynomial that cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials. Therefore, the concept of a polynomial must be defined to understand what an irreducible polynomial is.

The Galois group of a polynomial is defined as the group of automorphisms of the splitting field of the polynomial. Therefore, the concept of a polynomial must be defined to understand what the Galois group is.
An element is integral over a ring if it satisfies certain conditions with respect to a ring homomorphism. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what an integral element is.

A trivial algebraic field extension is defined as an algebraic field extension where every element of the extended field is algebraic over the base field. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what a trivial algebraic field extension is.

The centralizer of a subset in a group is defined as the set of elements in the group that commute with every element of the subset. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a centralizer is.
An element of a set is defined as an object belonging to a set. Therefore, the concept of a set must be defined to understand what an element of a set is.
